sn22.57:1.2.pli: “Sattaṭṭhānakusalo, bhikkhave, bhikkhu tividhūpaparikkhī imasmiṃ dhammavinaye kevalī vusitavā uttamapurisoti vuccati.
sn22.57:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, in this teaching and training a mendicant who is skilled in seven cases and who examines in three ways is called consummate, accomplished, a supreme person.

sn22.57:1.3.eng: And how is a mendicant skilled in seven cases?
sn22.57:1.3.comm: The “seven” are the four noble truths from the previous discourse, plus the “gratification” triad from SN 22.26.

sn22.57:1.4.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu rūpaṃ pajānāti, rūpasamudayaṃ pajānāti, rūpanirodhaṃ pajānāti, rūpanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānāti;
sn22.57:1.4.eng: It’s when a mendicant understands form, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.

sn22.57:1.5.pli: rūpassa assādaṃ pajānāti, rūpassa ādīnavaṃ pajānāti, rūpassa nissaraṇaṃ pajānāti;
sn22.57:1.5.eng: They understand form’s gratification, drawback, and escape.

sn22.57:1.9.pli: viññāṇaṃ pajānāti, viññāṇasamudayaṃ pajānāti, viññāṇanirodhaṃ pajānāti, viññāṇanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānāti;
sn22.57:1.9.eng: consciousness, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.

sn22.57:1.10.pli: viññāṇassa assādaṃ pajānāti, viññāṇassa ādīnavaṃ pajānāti, viññāṇassa nissaraṇaṃ pajānāti.
sn22.57:1.10.eng: They understand consciousness’s gratification, drawback, and escape.

sn22.57:2.2.pli: Cattāro ca mahābhūtā, catunnañca mahābhūtānaṃ upādāya rūpaṃ.
sn22.57:2.2.eng: The four principal states, and form derived from the four principal states.

sn22.57:2.6.pli: Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo rūpanirodhagāminī paṭipadā, seyyathidaṃ—
sn22.57:2.6.eng: The practice that leads to the cessation of form is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn22.57:2.7.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn22.57:3.1.pli: Yaṃ rūpaṃ paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṃ somanassaṃ—
sn22.57:3.1.eng: The pleasure and happiness that arise from form: this is its gratification.

sn22.57:3.3.eng: That form is impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback.

sn22.57:3.5.eng: Removing and giving up desire and greed for form: this is its escape.

sn22.57:4.1.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā evaṃ rūpaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ rūpasamudayaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ rūpanirodhaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ rūpanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ abhiññāya;
sn22.57:4.1.eng: Those ascetics and brahmins who have directly known form in this way—and its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation;

sn22.57:4.2.pli: evaṃ rūpassa assādaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ rūpassa ādīnavaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ rūpassa nissaraṇaṃ abhiññāya rūpassa nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipannā, te suppaṭipannā.
sn22.57:4.2.eng: its gratification, drawback, and escape—and are practicing for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding form: they are practicing well.

sn22.57:4.3.pli: Ye suppaṭipannā, te imasmiṃ dhammavinaye gādhanti.
sn22.57:4.3.eng: Those who practice well have a footing in this teaching and training.

sn22.57:5.1.pli: Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā evaṃ rūpaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ rūpasamudayaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ rūpanirodhaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ rūpanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ abhiññāya;
sn22.57:5.1.eng: Those ascetics and brahmins who have directly known form in this way—and its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation;

sn22.57:5.2.pli: evaṃ rūpassa assādaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ rūpassa ādīnavaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ rūpassa nissaraṇaṃ abhiññāya rūpassa nibbidā virāgā nirodhā anupādā vimuttā, te suvimuttā.
sn22.57:5.2.eng: its gratification, drawback, and escape—and due to disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding form, are freed by not grasping: they are well freed.

sn22.57:5.3.eng: Those who are well freed are consummate ones.

sn22.57:5.4.pli: Ye kevalino vaṭṭaṃ tesaṃ natthi paññāpanāya.
sn22.57:5.4.eng: For consummate ones, there is no cycle of rebirths to be found.

sn22.57:6.2.eng: There are these six classes of feeling:

sn22.57:6.8.pli: Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo vedanānirodhagāminī paṭipadā, seyyathidaṃ—
sn22.57:6.8.eng: The practice that leads to the cessation of feelings is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn22.57:6.9.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn22.57:7.1.pli: Yaṃ vedanaṃ paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṃ somanassaṃ—
sn22.57:7.1.eng: The pleasure and happiness that arise from feeling: this is its gratification.

sn22.57:7.3.eng: That feeling is impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback.

sn22.57:7.5.eng: Removing and giving up desire and greed for feeling: this is its escape. …

sn22.57:8.1.pli: Ye hi, keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā evaṃ vedanaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ vedanāsamudayaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ vedanānirodhaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ vedanānirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ abhiññāya;

sn22.57:8.2.pli: evaṃ vedanāya assādaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ vedanāya ādīnavaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ vedanāya nissaraṇaṃ abhiññāya vedanāya nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipannā, te suppaṭipannā.

sn22.57:8.3.pli: Ye suppaṭipannā, te imasmiṃ dhammavinaye gādhanti.

sn22.57:9.1.pli: Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā evaṃ vedanaṃ abhiññāya …pe…

sn22.57:10.2.eng: There are these six classes of perception:

sn22.57:10.3.pli: rūpasaññā, saddasaññā, gandhasaññā, rasasaññā, phoṭṭhabbasaññā, dhammasaññā.
sn22.57:10.3.eng: perceptions of sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas.

sn22.57:10.7.pli: Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo saññānirodhagāminī paṭipadā, seyyathidaṃ—
sn22.57:10.7.eng: The practice that leads to the cessation of perceptions is simply this noble eightfold path …

sn22.57:11.2.eng: There are these six classes of intention:

sn22.57:11.8.pli: Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo saṅkhāranirodhagāminī paṭipadā, seyyathidaṃ—
sn22.57:11.8.eng: The practice that leads to the cessation of choices is simply this noble eightfold path …

sn22.57:12.1.pli: Yaṃ saṅkhāre paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṃ somanassaṃ—

sn22.57:13.1.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā evaṃ saṅkhāre abhiññāya, evaṃ saṅkhārasamudayaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ saṅkhāranirodhaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ saṅkhāranirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ abhiññāya …pe… saṅkhārānaṃ nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipannā te suppaṭipannā.

sn22.57:13.2.pli: Ye suppaṭipannā, te imasmiṃ dhammavinaye gādhanti …pe…

sn22.57:14.2.eng: There are these six classes of consciousness:

sn22.57:14.3.pli: cakkhuviññāṇaṃ, sotaviññāṇaṃ, ghānaviññāṇaṃ, jivhāviññāṇaṃ, kāyaviññāṇaṃ, manoviññāṇaṃ.
sn22.57:14.3.eng: eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind consciousness.

sn22.57:14.5.eng: Consciousness originates from name and form.

sn22.57:14.6.eng: When name and form cease, consciousness ceases.

sn22.57:14.7.pli: Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo viññāṇanirodhagāminī paṭipadā, seyyathidaṃ—
sn22.57:14.7.eng: The practice that leads to the cessation of consciousness is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn22.57:14.8.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn22.57:15.1.pli: Yaṃ viññāṇaṃ paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṃ somanassaṃ—
sn22.57:15.1.eng: The pleasure and happiness that arise from consciousness: this is its gratification.

sn22.57:15.3.eng: That consciousness is impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback.

sn22.57:15.5.eng: Removing and giving up desire and greed for consciousness: this is its escape.

sn22.57:16.1.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā evaṃ viññāṇaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ viññāṇasamudayaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ viññāṇanirodhaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ viññāṇanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ abhiññāya;
sn22.57:16.1.eng: Those ascetics and brahmins who have directly known consciousness in this way—and its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation;

sn22.57:16.2.pli: evaṃ viññāṇassa assādaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ viññāṇassa ādīnavaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ viññāṇassa nissaraṇaṃ abhiññāya viññāṇassa nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipannā, te suppaṭipannā.
sn22.57:16.2.eng: its gratification, drawback, and escape—and are practicing for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding consciousness: they are practicing well.

sn22.57:16.3.pli: Ye suppaṭipannā, te imasmiṃ dhammavinaye gādhanti.
sn22.57:16.3.eng: Those who practice well have a footing  in this teaching and training.

sn22.57:17.1.pli: Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā evaṃ viññāṇaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ viññāṇasamudayaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ viññāṇanirodhaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ viññāṇanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ abhiññāya;
sn22.57:17.1.eng: Those ascetics and brahmins who have directly known consciousness in this way—and its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation;

sn22.57:17.2.pli: evaṃ viññāṇassa assādaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ viññāṇassa ādīnavaṃ abhiññāya, evaṃ viññāṇassa nissaraṇaṃ abhiññāya viññāṇassa nibbidā virāgā nirodhā anupādā vimuttā, te suvimuttā.
sn22.57:17.2.eng: its gratification, drawback, and escape—and due to disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding consciousness, are freed by not grasping: they are well freed.

sn22.57:17.3.eng: Those who are well freed are consummate ones.

sn22.57:17.4.pli: Ye kevalino vaṭṭaṃ tesaṃ natthi paññāpanāya.
sn22.57:17.4.eng: For consummate ones, there is no cycle of rebirths to be found.

sn22.57:17.5.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sattaṭṭhānakusalo hoti.
sn22.57:17.5.eng: That’s how a mendicant is skilled in seven cases.

sn22.57:18.1.eng: And how does a mendicant examine in three ways?
sn22.57:18.1.comm: The verb “examine” (upaparikkhati) is frequently used for someone who has learned the teachings, then internally reflects on their meaning.

sn22.57:18.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhātuso upaparikkhati, āyatanaso upaparikkhati, paṭiccasamuppādaso upaparikkhati.
sn22.57:18.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant examines by way of the elements, sense fields, and dependent origination.
sn22.57:18.2.comm: These three, along with the aggregates, are the major wisdom topics, mentioned together also at MN 115:3.3. More commonly, the aggregates, sense fields, and elements are mentioned as a summary of the Buddha’s wisdom teachings (SN 8.12:3.2, SN 35.31:1.21, Thig 5.8:2.2, etc.).

sn22.57:18.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu tividhūpaparikkhī hoti.
sn22.57:18.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant examines in three ways.

sn22.57:18.4.pli: Sattaṭṭhānakusalo, bhikkhave, bhikkhu tividhūpaparikkhī, imasmiṃ dhammavinaye kevalī vusitavā ‘uttamapuriso’ti vuccatī”ti.
sn22.57:18.4.eng: In this teaching and training, a mendicant who is skilled in seven cases and who examines in three ways is called consummate, accomplished, a supreme person.”

sn22.58:1.2.pli: “Tathāgato, bhikkhave, arahaṃ sammāsambuddho rūpassa nibbidā virāgā nirodhā anupādā vimutto sammāsambuddhoti vuccati.
sn22.58:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, a Realized One, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha is freed by not grasping, due to disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding form. They’re called a fully awakened Buddha.

sn22.58:1.3.pli: Bhikkhupi, bhikkhave, paññāvimutto rūpassa nibbidā virāgā nirodhā anupādā vimutto paññāvimuttoti vuccati.
sn22.58:1.3.eng: A mendicant freed by wisdom is also freed by not grasping, due to disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding form. They’re called a mendicant freed by wisdom.
sn22.58:1.3.comm: The mendicant “freed by wisdom” is an arahant. Here it means any arahant, but sometimes it distinguishes one who has prioritized wisdom in their development (eg. MN 70:16.2).

sn22.58:2.1.pli: Tathāgato, bhikkhave, arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vedanāya nibbidā virāgā nirodhā anupādā vimutto sammāsambuddhoti vuccati.
sn22.58:2.1.eng: A Realized One, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha is freed by not grasping, due to disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding feeling …

sn22.58:2.2.pli: Bhikkhupi, bhikkhave, paññāvimutto vedanāya nibbidā …pe… paññāvimuttoti vuccati.

sn22.58:3.3.pli: viññāṇassa nibbidā virāgā nirodhā anupādā vimutto sammāsambuddhoti vuccati.
sn22.58:3.3.eng: consciousness. They’re called a fully awakened Buddha.

sn22.58:3.4.pli: Bhikkhupi, bhikkhave, paññāvimutto viññāṇassa nibbidā virāgā nirodhā anupādā vimutto paññāvimuttoti vuccati.
sn22.58:3.4.eng: A mendicant freed by wisdom is also freed by not grasping, due to disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding consciousness. They’re called a mendicant freed by wisdom.

sn22.58:4.1.pli: Tatra kho, bhikkhave, ko viseso, ko adhippayāso, kiṃ nānākaraṇaṃ, tathāgatassa arahato sammāsambuddhassa paññāvimuttena bhikkhunā”ti?
sn22.58:4.1.eng: What, then, is the difference between a Realized One, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha, and a mendicant freed by wisdom?”

sn22.58:4.2.pli: “Bhagavaṃmūlakā no, bhante, dhammā bhagavaṃnettikā bhagavaṃpaṭisaraṇā. Sādhu vata, bhante, bhagavantaññeva paṭibhātu etassa bhāsitassa attho. Bhagavato sutvā bhikkhū dhāressantī”ti.
sn22.58:4.2.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. He is our guide and our refuge. Sir, may the Buddha himself please clarify the meaning of this. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

sn22.58:4.3.pli: “Tena hi, bhikkhave, suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
sn22.58:4.3.eng: “Well then, mendicants, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

sn22.58:4.4.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

sn22.58:5.1.pli: “Tathāgato, bhikkhave, arahaṃ sammāsambuddho anuppannassa maggassa uppādetā, asañjātassa maggassa sañjanetā, anakkhātassa maggassa akkhātā maggaññū, maggavidū, maggakovido;
sn22.58:5.1.eng: “The Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha gave rise to the unarisen path, gave birth to the unborn path, and explained the unexplained path. He is the knower of the path, the discoverer of the path, the expert on the path.

sn22.58:5.2.pli: maggānugā ca, bhikkhave, etarahi sāvakā viharanti pacchā samannāgatā.
sn22.58:5.2.eng: And now the disciples live following the path; they acquire it later.

sn22.58:5.3.pli: Ayaṃ kho, bhikkhave, viseso, ayaṃ adhippayāso, idaṃ nānākaraṇaṃ tathāgatassa arahato sammāsambuddhassa paññāvimuttena bhikkhunā”ti.
sn22.58:5.3.eng: This is the difference between a Realized One, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha, and a mendicant freed by wisdom.”

sn22.59:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā bārāṇasiyaṃ viharati isipatane migadāye.
sn22.59:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Varanasi, in the deer park at Isipatana.
sn22.59:1.1.comm: This is the famous “second discourse”, the story of which is told in the Vinaya (Kd 1:6.32.1). At the conclusion of the Dhammacakkappavattanasutta (SN 56.11), when Koṇḍañña became a stream-enterer, the Buddha continued to teach the five ascetics over several days. Eventually, all five realized stream-entry and went forth officially as Buddhist mendicants. Knowing they were ready, he taught them about not-self. In the first discourse, the Buddha referred to the five aggregates “in brief”, and now he draws that teaching out in more detail. Thus the second discourse is a commentary on a line in the first discourse.

sn22.59:1.2.pli: Tatra kho bhagavā pañcavaggiye bhikkhū āmantesi:
sn22.59:1.2.eng: There the Buddha addressed the group of five mendicants:

sn22.59:2.1.comm: The “self” (attā, Sanskrit ātman) is the cardinal doctrine of the Upaniṣads, whereas the five ascetics were likely Jains, or at least from a similar group. The Jains typically used jīva (“soul”) to indicate the radiant essence purified by austerities, which remains eternal as an individual, separate entity. This contrasts with the Upaniṣadic self, which merged into union with the divine Brahma. These terms, however, are not used exclusively, nor are their definitions consistent. The Buddha is casting a wide net, beginning with “form” to capture the most basic conceptions of self, and moving through successively more refined conceptions of self, culminating with the most subtle conception of the Upaniṣads, the identification of self with consciousness.

sn22.59:2.2.pli: Rūpañca hidaṃ, bhikkhave, attā abhavissa, nayidaṃ rūpaṃ ābādhāya saṃvatteyya, labbhetha ca rūpe:
sn22.59:2.2.eng: For if form were self, it wouldn’t lead to affliction. And you could compel form:
sn22.59:2.2.comm: This conditional argument against the “self” is found only here in this form, although the same manner of argument is also at MN 35:13.4. See too the Buddha’s discussion with Poṭṭhapāda on various kinds of “self” (DN 9:21.4).

sn22.59:2.3.pli: ‘evaṃ me rūpaṃ hotu, evaṃ me rūpaṃ mā ahosī’ti.
sn22.59:2.3.eng: ‘May my form be like this! May it not be like that!’
sn22.59:2.3.comm: This responds to the “inner controller” (antaryāmin) of Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 3.7. Uddālaka, having learned this from the centaur Kabandha in Madra (near modern Islamabad), challenges Yājñavalkya, who explains it as the self who lives in the midst of all things, unknown but knowing, controlling all from within.

sn22.59:2.4.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, rūpaṃ anattā, tasmā rūpaṃ ābādhāya saṃvattati, na ca labbhati rūpe:
sn22.59:2.4.eng: But because form is not-self, it leads to affliction. And you can’t compel form:

sn22.59:2.5.pli: ‘evaṃ me rūpaṃ hotu, evaṃ me rūpaṃ mā ahosī’ti.
sn22.59:2.5.eng: ‘May my form be like this! May it not be like that!’

sn22.59:3.2.pli: Vedanā ca hidaṃ, bhikkhave, attā abhavissa, nayidaṃ vedanā ābādhāya saṃvatteyya, labbhetha ca vedanāya:

sn22.59:3.3.pli: ‘evaṃ me vedanā hotu, evaṃ me vedanā mā ahosī’ti.

sn22.59:3.4.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, vedanā anattā, tasmā vedanā ābādhāya saṃvattati, na ca labbhati vedanāya:

sn22.59:3.5.pli: ‘evaṃ me vedanā hotu, evaṃ me vedanā mā ahosī’ti.

sn22.59:4.3.pli: Saṅkhārā ca hidaṃ, bhikkhave, attā abhavissaṃsu, nayidaṃ saṅkhārā ābādhāya saṃvatteyyuṃ, labbhetha ca saṅkhāresu:

sn22.59:4.4.pli: ‘evaṃ me saṅkhārā hontu, evaṃ me saṅkhārā mā ahesun’ti.

sn22.59:4.5.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, saṅkhārā anattā, tasmā saṅkhārā ābādhāya saṃvattanti, na ca labbhati saṅkhāresu:

sn22.59:4.6.pli: ‘evaṃ me saṅkhārā hontu, evaṃ me saṅkhārā mā ahesun’ti.

sn22.59:5.2.pli: Viññāṇañca hidaṃ, bhikkhave, attā abhavissa, nayidaṃ viññāṇaṃ ābādhāya saṃvatteyya, labbhetha ca viññāṇe:
sn22.59:5.2.eng: For if consciousness were self, it wouldn’t lead to affliction. And you could compel consciousness:

sn22.59:5.3.pli: ‘evaṃ me viññāṇaṃ hotu, evaṃ me viññāṇaṃ mā ahosī’ti.
sn22.59:5.3.eng: ‘May my consciousness be like this! May it not be like that!’

sn22.59:5.4.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, viññāṇaṃ anattā, tasmā viññāṇaṃ ābādhāya saṃvattati, na ca labbhati viññāṇe:
sn22.59:5.4.eng: But because consciousness is not-self, it leads to affliction. And you can’t compel consciousness:

sn22.59:5.5.pli: ‘evaṃ me viññāṇaṃ hotu, evaṃ me viññāṇaṃ mā ahosī’ti.
sn22.59:5.5.eng: ‘May my consciousness be like this! May it not be like that!’

sn22.59:6.1.comm: While first passage is unique, the remainder of the discourse is repeated countless times throughout the discourses. The Buddha engages his audience in question and answer, stimulating reflection and giving encouragement.

sn22.59:6.4.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn22.59:6.4.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn22.59:6.6.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
sn22.59:6.6.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

sn22.59:6.7.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn22.59:6.8.comm: To understand this argument, we must bear in mind that the “self” was a metaphysical theory of an abiding, eternal reality that is one’s truest essence, from which we have become alienated due to defiling influences. Salvation from the travails of the world lies in realizing this essential truth. It follows that what is impermanent cannot be the self, because when it disappears the self would also disappear (DN 15:29.4). And what is suffering cannot be the self, because our true essence is free of impurities and thus essentially blissful, radiant, and all-knowing. This salvific self cannot be identified with something that brings only pain (SN 22.60:5.1). | This metaphysical “self” has only a contingent relationship with the empirical “self” of psychology or popular usage. The psychological self grows and changes, and must develop emotional wholeness and coherence for a person to become a healthy individual. If someone with a fractured psychological self latches on to the Buddhist teaching of no metaphysical self, they can easily mistake one for the other, leading to further disintegration of the psyche. That is why contemplation of not-self is recommended for those who have practiced samādhi, a state of deep emotional integration.

sn22.59:6.14.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn22.59:6.14.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn22.59:6.16.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
sn22.59:6.16.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

sn22.59:6.17.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn22.59:7.1.pli: “Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, yaṃ kiñci rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ rūpaṃ: ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
sn22.59:7.1.eng: “So you should truly see any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn22.59:8.1.pli: Yā kāci vedanā atītānāgatapaccuppannā ajjhattā vā bahiddhā vā …pe… yā dūre santike vā, sabbā vedanā: ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
sn22.59:8.1.eng: Any kind of feeling at all …

sn22.59:9.1.eng: Any kind of perception at all …

sn22.59:9.2.pli: ye keci saṅkhārā atītānāgatapaccuppannā ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā …pe… ye dūre santike vā, sabbe saṅkhārā: ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
sn22.59:9.2.eng: Any kind of choices at all …

sn22.59:10.1.pli: Yaṃ kiñci viññāṇaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ viññāṇaṃ: ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
sn22.59:10.1.eng: You should truly see any kind of consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all consciousness—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn22.59:11.1.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako rūpasmimpi nibbindati, vedanāyapi nibbindati, saññāyapi nibbindati, saṅkhāresupi nibbindati, viññāṇasmimpi nibbindati.
sn22.59:11.1.eng: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

sn22.59:11.2.pli: Nibbindaṃ virajjati; virāgā vimuccati. Vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti.
sn22.59:11.2.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

sn22.59:11.3.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
sn22.59:11.3.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn22.59:12.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

sn22.59:12.2.pli: Attamanā pañcavaggiyā bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanduṃ.
sn22.59:12.2.eng: Satisfied, the group of five mendicants approved what the Buddha said.

sn22.59:12.3.pli: Imasmiñca pana veyyākaraṇasmiṃ bhaññamāne pañcavaggiyānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ anupādāya āsavehi cittāni vimucciṃsūti.
sn22.59:12.3.eng: And while this discourse was being spoken, the minds of the group of five mendicants were freed from defilements by not grasping.

sn22.6:1.2.comm: Mendicants should “meditate in retreat” (paṭisallāṇe yogamāpajjatha) in order to understand the six senses (SN 35.100, SN 35.161) and the four noble truths (SN 56.2). | Pali yoga (“yoke”) can mean “effort”, as in yogaṁ āpajjati, “engage in effort (regarding that)”, which I render “get involved (in that)” (AN 7.28:1.7). Compare the English expression “harness energy”.  The related expression yogamāpajjatha is literally “engage in effort in retreat”. This means primarily to meditate, and indeed Pali yoga shades into the sense “meditation, immersion” (Dhp 282:1), a sense that anticipates Patañjali’s definition of yoga as “the cessation of transformations of mind” (Yogasūtra 1.2).

sn22.6:1.3.eng: A mendicant in retreat truly understands.

sn22.6:1.5.pli: Rūpassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañca, vedanāya samudayañca atthaṅgamañca, saññāya samudayañca atthaṅgamañca, saṅkhārānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca, viññāṇassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañca …pe…
sn22.6:1.5.eng: The origin and ending of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness. …”

sn22.6:1.6.eng: (Tell in full as in the previous discourse.)
